div1.head: Memorandum from Henry Rose Carter to James A. Haynes, February 20, 1915
div1.opener:
COLUMBIA RAILWAY, GAS AND ELECTRIC COMPANY
COLUMBIA, S. C. Feb. 20th, 1915.
EDWIN W. ROBERTSON, PRESIDENT & TREASURER.
ALFRED WALLACE, GENERAL MANAGER.
Dr. Jas. A. Haynes,
City.
div1.p: MEMORANDUM.

The object of our visit to water imponded at Parr Shoals
is primarily to advise what measures should be adopted to lessen the
production of mosquitoes by said water as much as may be. This then
will be set forth in this paper rather than a report of the condition
of the pond. Obviously only a physical surevy of the pond was possible
at this season of the year and such a survey must leave many ponts
involving the breeding of mosquitoes undetermined. TOf this a liogical
survey would be necessary during the mosquitoe breeding season--pro-
bably two of them.
We will, however, mention two peculiar features of this pond.
(1). Its nearly constant level.

The only rises are due to freshets and the only falls to a low
stage of water in the river which falls is minimized almost to the
vanishing point by the obligation to keep the water up to the top of
the dam.

(2). The large amount of flat land in the pond covered by the
thick growth of saplings or underbrush.

The first condition, the high level maintained during the
mosquitoe breeding season, prevents having bare banks at this season
which are a valuable factor in preventing mosquitoe production. The
second prevents waive action against the banks of the pond and may lead in
COLUMBIA RAILWAY, GAS AND ELECTRIC COMPANY
COLUMBIA, S. C.
EDWIN W. ROBERTSON, PRESIDENT & TREASURER.
ALFRED WALLACE, GENERAL MANAGER.
#2.
in places to breeding in the pond distant from the bank.
The general measures propsed are.

Primarily to increase fish control of the breeding and to
a less degree increase wave action against the banks.
To Promote Fish Control.

(1). Clean the banks of brush and drift. (sticks, pine needles, etc)
from the ordinary high level in the summer to as far out in the pond
as one can reach in low water.

The brush should be cut as low as practicable so as not to
project above the level of low water or sprout again. The drift or
flotage should be dragged ashore with a rake. Trees and large saplings,
except pine trees in this area need not be cut. Pine trees, however,
in this area should be either cut or ringed, as should those on the bank close
enough to drop needles in it. Laps of trees even a little distance
outside of this area should be dragged ashore. The object of this work
is to remove the brush, etc., against which floatage lodges and shelters
mosquitoe larvae. This is most efficiently done when the water is lowest
for then the brush can be cut down lowest - hence in the Falls. In the present
condition of the pond it should be done before the hatching season--
beginningfinishing it about May 1st. The racking of the banks should be repeated
from time to time during the summer after the brush and drift collect
again. After the first cleaning the subsequent racking will be easily
and rapidly done.

COLUMBIA RAILWAY, GAS AND ELECTRIC COMPANY
COLUMBIA, S. C.

EDWIN W. ROBERTSON, PRESIDENT & TREASURER.
ALFRED WALLACE, GENERAL MANAGER.

(2). As the pond receeds watch should be kept for the pools left
behind it. Such of those as will last over 15 days should be connected
with the pond by ditches either draining them or letting in fish.
The removal of clumps of blurushes in such places on the edge of the
pond is advised where it is practicable.

(3). The hammocks of floatage in the edges of the driftdrowned wood
should be keptset adrift. These hammocks are on both banks of the old
river bed, most on the East and were visited after coming out of
Cannon's Creek with LePrince. We do not know that these hammocks will
produce mosquitoes, but it seems not unlikely. Beginning up the river
and working down it can be quickly done.

From the work contemplated in (1)such banks may be excepted
as (a) are exposed to wave action (b) are clean and bare, or (c) are
at a considerable distance-say three quarters of a mile-from a res-
idence. This will enable one to concentrate for thorough work where
it is most needed.

On the other hand in the flatooded parts of the valleys, creeks,
branches, sloughs and in the neighborhood of residences special pains
should be taken to make the cleaning thorough.

Three quarters of a mile is farther by 50% more than is usually allowed
for mosquitoes carrying malaria, but the allowance for this distance
of safety should be greater if measured from a place breeding very
profusely than from one breeding less, especially if there be no blood
supply for the insect closer.

COLUMBIA RAILWAY, GAS AND ELECTRIC COMPANY
COLUMBIA, S. C.

EDWIN W. ROBERTSON, PRESIDENT & TREASURER.
ALFRED WALLACE, GENERAL MANAGER.

By banks we mean not only the banks of the main pond,
but the banks of Islands & mud flats and those of the sloughs making
off from the river.
To Promote Wave Action.

This work of clearing the banks will generally be unneces-
sary where the river is running in its natural banks. This begins for
the West side about a mile and a quarter below Dawkins Ferry. For the
lower part of this district, however, where the river although within
banks is over the so called false banks, it will be necessary to ex-
amine and when the brush on the false banks, willows namemainly, is thick
enough to protect the banks from wave action this must be cut down
although it may be some yards out in the stream. Willow unless cut
so as to have its stump covered by water most of the time will sprout
again. Hence cut as low as possible and at extreme low water.

When the water is within the false banks nothing need be done
in the way of bank clearing, but the creeks, branches and sloughs
which come in up to slack water must be examined and these banks treated
under the principles given before. It may be noted that the deep-
ening of the mouths of these streams as they are backed up let in fish
and are more apt to do good than do harm. This is especially true
in sloughs containing marshes.

All of this work looks to increase fish control and wave action
at the bank. In general in large ponds mosquitoe production has been
found to be confined to the banks but this, and these measures well
COLUMBIA RAILWAY, GAS AND ELECTRIC COMPANY
COLUMBIA, S. C.
EDWIN W. ROBERTSON, PRESIDENT & TREASURER.
ALFRED WALLACE, GENERAL MANAGER.
#5.
carried out will lessen, we believe greatly lessen, this production.
It is not, however, pretended that in ponds with the physical character-
istics of some parts of this one production of anopheles mosquitoes
may not occur away from the banks. Against this the measures outlined
above would be futile. Nor obviously will they furnish productection
against anopheles mosquitoes bred above in back water of the pond in breeding places
in running streams, seepage - out crops etc., not caused by the pond.
A number of which were seen during this trip. It may be noted that
anopheles mosquitoes breed by preference in small pools of clear water
in grass, and in pools & in the grassy edges of small running streams. They do not
breed in foul water or in water which from standing is covered with
a dirty scum.
ALGAE.

If algae, “green frog moss”, becomes prevalent later in the
year summer and is found to be sheltering larvae from the fish.
Dragging a crocus sack of “Blue vitriol” (SulphurateSulphate of Copper), behind
a boat over the infected area will kill it all. This should be re-
peated when it is necessary. Algae are most apt to show in the
very still shallow water, in creeks and inlets.
Fish Propagation.

It would be well to see if the Carolina top minnow can be
propagated economically in the pond. There are very efficient
minnows in the pond at Hartsville, and this pond may be alreadyreadily stoppedcked.
COLUMBIA RAILWAY, GAS AND ELECTRIC COMPANY

EDWIN W. ROBERTSON, PRESIDENT & TREASURER.
ALFRED WALLACE, GENERAL MANAGER.
COLUMBIA, S. C.
A Few Special Places.

(1) Dawkins: For the bad section of marsh North West of the
station which has always been a place suitable for breeding mos-
quitoes, cut a ditch parallel to a contouraround the base of the hill
so as to cut off the hill seepage. This will run to the North East
and East of the old marsh. Cut it deep enough for the fish from the
pond to enter it. W Clean the brush out of the old ditches
up to back water so that fish can get in them. This is about all that
can be done for this place, which we have said evidently was a breeding
place before the pond was formed.

Next to the ferry cut a short straight ditch short ditch straight
out from the sloughs to the river. Also run a ditch down the length of this slough to the River For both of these places at
Dawkins burning the weeds and long grass should precede the ditching.

(2). Hiller's Creek: On the bank from the embankment to around
the bight to the right (standing with ones back to the road) needs
careful cleaning, especially an old fence on the bank of the field and a lot of
pine needles in the bight. Hereto a lot of brush & trees have been cut from
the bank so as to fall in the creek. Move it out, Higher up this creek, well above
back water, and the influence of the pond, are a number of sloughs, which
are are physically suited to breeding anopheles mosquitoes.

(3). Coles Creek: Up at the head of back water needs attention
. Above back water and beyond the influence of the pond it too has
places which are physically suited for breeding.

(4). Trestle near Mr. Cole's House: Clean banks of the bight
very carefully and for some distance above and below for this house
is very near the river.

COLUMBIA RAILWAY, GAS AND ELECTRIC COMPANY
COLUMBIA, S. C.

EDWIN W. ROBERTSON, PRESIDENT & TREASURER.
ALFRED WALLACE, GENERAL MANAGER.

(5) Sloughs above Dawkins where we ate dinner. Burn off
the grass, cut brush with an axe and open ditch to let fish in.

This was evidently a marsh breeding before the pond
was made and will need be made better when this ditch was cut than it
was before the pond was made
CLEANING OF BANKS ALREADY DONE.

The cleaning of the banks on the North side of Cannon Creek
from the bridge to near its mouth is well done and although it has
been done about five weeks, in only a very few places had any float-
age collected on the bank. It could probably go at this rate nearly
a month longer without being foul enough to require re-raking. Of
course it is unnecessary to do this, however, until near the first
flight of Anopheles, About May 1stsay the early part of May. It may require raking, however,
oftener than this when the pine-needles fall from the trees in this
part of the pond, and much less often when all such needles are
down. Nearly all of this work of banks cleaning, especially after
the first cutting out of brush would be unnecessary if the pond could
raised and lowered during the summer season. It would be exceedingly
advantageous, from a sanitary standpoint, if the level could be kept
as high as possible--say to June, and as low as possible in August
and September.- With such weekly and daily rises as are practicable
during this - the breeding season. This would give us clean banks
during this season.
